discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - May 2022

content.content: All, Please see below for the May update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, DAI expenses were up at 3.2M in May, 0.6M lower than forecast. Forecasted expenses are expected to stabilize around 3.7M/month by June, a 44M annual run-rate (in line with what we forecasted in April). Oracle gas expenses continue to trend lower based on lower network congestion and OCU work to minimize gas expenses in a secular way. We have started proactive work around reducing burn-rates to mitigate the impact of the bear market on the protocol. The different initiatives are all captured with the bear-prep tag on the forums. Link here if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets.  image2476×856 429 KB   image2018×434 100 KB   image832×202 21.3 KB  Thanks as usual to @Kayleigh for the help putting it together. Edit: Thanks @Dracaena27 and @wouter for the SES forecast correction for Jun/Jul/Aug
What does “All other CUs” stand for in the first table? All core units seem to be included in the table already so I would expect that row to be zero. Special purpose funds?
It adds all the Core Units below that row. The total at the bottom doesn’t aggregate it.
This topic was automatically closed 14 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - January 2022

content.content: All, Please see below for the January update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, our DAI expenses have increased to $2.6M in January and our forecasted expenses will increase to $2.9M/month by April, a $35.2M annual run rate. Adding in estimated annual Oracle gas costs of $6.8M (January actuals of $563K annualized), brings us to an annual cash burn rate of $42M, a $12.9M decrease from prior month’s estimate. Over the past two weeks, we’ve seen a significant decrease in Oracle gas expenses, driven by lower Gwei prices. During this period we’ve been spending ~2 ETH per day, or about $150K/month at current ETH prices. This is too small to be a meaningful sample size and extrapolate off of, but quite positive to see as these cost savings drop directly to the bottom line. I’ve included a tab for the MKR vesting schedule for every Core Unit and summarized the P&L impact incurred to date based on the vested price. To date this only covers Risk due to the 300 MKR retroactive payment approved by MKR holders, but this will increase by 4.1K additional MKR vesting by April, primarily driven by the PECU. Link is provided at the very bottom if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets.  image1538×587 94.5 KB   image1451×149 12.7 KB   File with vesting schedule can be found here .
This topic was automatically closed 90 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - February 2022

content.content: All, Please see below for the February update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, DAI expenses decreased to $2.3M in February ($0.3M vs prior month) and our forecasted expenses are expected to increase to $3M/month by April, a $36.3M annual run-rate. Adding in estimated annual Oracle gas costs of $5.1M (trailing three month average of $427K annualized), brings us to an annual cash burn rate of $41.4M, a $0.6M decrease from prior month’s estimate. Over the past four weeks, we’ve seen a significant decrease in Oracle gas expenses, driven by lower Gwei prices due to lower NFT trading volumes. During this period we’ve been spending ~2 ETH per day, or about $150K/month at current ETH prices. This is too small to be a meaningful sample size and extrapolate off of, but quite positive to see as these cost savings drop directly to the bottom line. The MKR vesting schedule for every Core Unit and summarized the P&L impact incurred to date based on the vested price has also been included. To date this only covers Risk due to the 300 MKR retroactive payment approved by MKR holders, but this will increase by 4.1K additional MKR vesting by April, primarily driven by the PECU. Link is provided at the very bottom if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets.  image2388×911 199 KB   image2253×358 28.1 KB    File with vesting schedule can be found here.

Aes:  Over the past four weeks, we’ve seen a significant decrease in Oracle gas expenses, driven by lower Gwei prices due to lower NFT trading volumes.   This is interesting. I noticed much lower Gwei but didn’t think NFT trading volume was down. Good to know.

if apparently he lost 80% of liquidity, have people already forgotten about the nfts??   TweakTown – 15 Mar 22    NFT sales plummet by 80% and trigger the 'great NFT sell-off' Daily NFT trade volume on OpenSea is reportedly down by some 80% and it could signify what media calls 'the great NFT sell-off'
As the saying goes, fashions come and go. But Maker is forever!

NFTs, like crypto, go up and down. If sales are down, how is that a great sell off? Isn’t that a lack of selling ? I’m not able to look at the raw data cited in this article but the perhaps the original author, or authors, could have thought of a better gimmick as opposed to “sell-off” to emphasize a lack of sales. What is interesting about the article is that it only pertains to sales on opensea and fails to take into consideration that there are other platforms and the like, as well as that people may be staking their NFTs, or holding them for other reasons (such as the massive amount of airdrops people are receiving for holding- $APE, etc.). Most importantly, this article fails to discuss the trade volume going back to the summer of 2021, which was referred to as the summer of NFTs.  If I recall, subsequent to the summer the trade volume dipped only to sore back in the start of this year (as is evident from the chart in this article).  Seems to me the article is more FUD

I understand your point, it was just a sarcastic question, but in general the interest of the public has fallen on the nfts, I hope it picks up. My intention wasn’t to create FUD haha. image1366×653 34.8 KB

The same thing that is occurring throughout public markets is occurring in NFTS—dispersion. Total volumes/interest may be down but strong projects on Ethereum and Solana are thriving. Not that this has any bearing on our oracles cost.

lol, no FUD from you, the article is FUD. I don’t know what that chart is and where the data comes from, but that chart indicates the all time high being in February 2022 ? From what I recall NFT trade volume shot down after the summer hard. I don’t see that indicated in this chart at all. Is this based upon OpenSea and/or another platform ?

I found this, I have no idea if it’s accurate but it looks way different.  image1695×1034 60 KB     dune.xyz    Dune Analytics Blockchain ecosystem analytics by and for the community. Explore and share data from Ethereum, xDai, Polygon, Optimism, BSC and Solana for free.
Not totally different but there seems to be a recent spike actually. I also couldn’t get it going back to the summer to check the numbers.

As far as I can see, this is the global trend of online searches for NFTs, including popular project terms. It is true what you say in summer there was an upturn but it is not in this measurement. Either way it shows the diminishing interest of the public. (google trend the first image) On a monthly basis discounting April for obvious reasons,there is a drop, not as strong as the media shows but there is a drop. We will see what happens with this trend  image877×500 13.7 KB

Yes, there is no “great sell off” that I see. That is my issue with that article. Also, this is only OpenSea and doesn’t include Solana NFTs (on their respective platforms), as well as WAX, etc. and also fails to include minting NFTs directly and the volume regarding same. Perhaps more people are minting as opposed to buying on secondary ? With the increase in NFT projects that would make sense but might be negligible anyway. Overall, I think it’s the market just being the market but I do expect the NFT bubble to burst (if not already). However, NFTs and the utility and technology behind them are going nowhere. Blockchain all the way !

discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - March 2022

content.content: All, Please see below for the March update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, DAI expenses increased to 2.5M in march (0.2M vs prior month), but 164k lower than had been forecasted 30 days ago. Our forecasted expenses are expected to increase to 3.5M/month by April, a 40M annual run-rate (4M higher run-rate vs what we forecasted in February). Estimated annual Oracle gas costs are 3.6M (vs 5.1M last month) based on a trailing three month average of 300K annualized (427K last month). This brings us to an annual cash burn rate of 43.6M, a 2.2M increase from prior month’s estimate. Oracle gas expenses continue to trend lower based on lower network congestion and ahead of any volatility or pickup on mainnet, it is an encouraging sign to see these savings go straight to the bottom line. The MKR vesting schedule for every Core Unit and summarized the P&L impact incurred to date based on the vested price has also been included. The next major vesting cliff takes place in June, mostly for the Oracles team. Full year MKR compensation in DAI terms is estimated at 17.3M. Link here if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets.  image1305×437 133 KB   image1232×250 33.6 KB   Thanks as usual to @Kayleigh for the help putting it together.
This topic was automatically closed 14 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - June 2022

content.content: Hello, Please see below for the June update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, reported DAI expenses as incurred were at 2.9M in May, 0.6M lower than forecast. Forecasted expenses are expected to stabilize around 3.2M/month by July, a 40M annual run-rate (slightly lower vs forecasted in April). We have started proactive work around reducing burn-rates to mitigate the impact of the bear market on the protocol. The different initiatives are all captured with the bear-prep tag on the forums. As a reminder the below is a mix of on-chain and reported expenses. Our monthly reports only ever rely on on-chain data for conservatism. Kindly let us know in case of any disagreements or discrepancies. Link here if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets.  image1232×375 118 KB   image1000×193 24.1 KB  Thanks a lot to @Juanbug for the help putting it together.
Events June does not look correct,  Looks like the forecast number (Without revenue offset) was used instead of the actuals.

Thanks @PonJerry, indeed. Reflected. EDIT: For clarity - Event CU has an 898k DAI annual budget starting May 2022. However, what @PonJerry has started doing is involving third-party partners who are cobranding the events and reducing the per event expense by sharing it with multiple sponsors. This will in effect reduce the projected run-rate for this CU as they are generating some amount of revenues to offset the expense of running the events. Eventually, the excess will be sent back to the surplus buffer. The above is now Events CU expenses, net of revenues including projected sponsor revenues for the next three months.

discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - December 2021

content.content: All, Please see below for the December update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, our DAI expenses have increased to $2.4M in December, or a $29M annual run rate. Onboarding the Tech Ops and Strategic Finance increases our Dai burn by about $250K per month or $3M annualized. Over the next few months we expect expenses to increase by roughly $130K per month - if we extrapolate this out, we would finish 2022 with approximately $39.3M in workforce expenses. Adding in estimated annual Oracle costs of $15.6M (Q1 estimate from Nik, annualized), brings us to an annual cash burn rate of $54.9M. Gwei prices have increased thus far in 2022, offsetting some of the oracle cost favorability driven by lower ETH prices. If the ETH price recovers, our oracle expenses could be significantly higher than estimated. I’ve included a tab for the MKR vesting schedule for every Core Unit and summarized the P&L impact incurred to date based on the vested price. To date this only covers Risk due to the 300 MKR retroactive payment approved by MKR holders, but this will increase by 700 additional MKR vesting at the end of March for the Risk Core Unit. Link is provided at the very bottom if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets. Note - Oracle expenses are currently listed as cash flows  image1539×591 68.5 KB   image1450×155 8.7 KB   File with vesting schedule can be found here.
Per FTE would be a more useful metric.
Only what was budgeted which is reflected in the forecast file. For actuals, we are working on a template which includes reporting of FTEs.

Would it be possible to provide a summary of these expenses similar to what is seen in the operating expenses section of this document? Potentially with a separate operating expense line item specifically for oracle gas costs. Looking through the your forecast file it seems that oracle expenses take up ~80% (15MM) of the oracle CU budget, and would probably be on par with a line item such as “Selling, general and administrative.” I took a stab at what i think might make sense in a copy of your document.
Nice summary, thanks! Fyi… This link MakerDAO Expenses - Dec 2021 Summary.xlsb - Google Drive opens an invalid xls file…even when I remove the b on the extension.
monkey.irish:  Fyi… This link MakerDAO Expenses - Dec 2021 Summary.xlsb - Google Drive opens an invalid xls file…even when I remove the b on the extension.   I was able to open it.
Odd. I usually click on it and can see the file. I tried downloading it and opening it locally as well. No go…says The file format is invalid.
Are you trying to open it with openoffice or other ODF applications? I’m able to open it with Excel just fine, it’s a binary spreadsheet format compatible with Excel.

discourse_list.title: MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - April 2022

content.content: All, Please see below for the April update of the monthly Core Unit expenses, including a forecast for the subsequent three months. As you can see from the below table, DAI expenses were flat at 2.5M in April, in line with forecasts. Forecasted expenses are expected to stabilize around 3.7M/month by May, a 44M annual run-rate (4M higher run-rate vs what we forecasted in March). Oracle gas expenses continue to trend lower based on lower network congestion and OCU work to minimize gas expenses in a secular way. Ahead of any volatility or pickup on mainnet, it is an encouraging sign to see these savings go straight to the bottom line. The MKR vesting schedule for every Core Unit and summarized the P&L impact incurred to date based on the vested price has also been included. The next major vesting cliff takes place in June, mostly for the Oracles team. Full year MKR compensation in DAI terms is estimated at 17.3M based on a 1,320 DAI market price. Link here if anyone would like to view the full vesting schedule and spreadsheets.  image1305×452 142 KB   image1232×211 39.7 KB   Thanks as usual to @Kayleigh for the help putting it together.

Extremely hard to estimate the variance for the upcoming months–on a scale of 1 to 10 (with 10 being accurate) how accurate are the April Actuals? Is SF receiving more accurate data from CU teams to make the actuals 100% accurate? Thanks in advance.

The actual themselves are reasonably accurate. We cross check against on chain transactions. In the event of a phasing issue or off chain transactions we have backups from CUs to verify. There are two sources of forecast error or ongoing variance. Firstly, budgets have a tendency to undershoot. We might not necessarily welcome this eg if a core unit could invest in something worthwhile but doesn’t it’s a double miss for the protocol - once for not having invested and twice for not being able to invest those funds elsewhere. With the new MIP40 requirements we tried to tackle this by asking Budgets to be evaluated through an ROI lens, ie if someone pads their budget it should look like too much money for the stated objectives. If it appears to be too good to be true they should be challenged to invest more. Secondly, forecasts are evolving quickly with the ongoing macroeconomic context. Hopefully this source of variance should stabilize soon as core units get used to operating at a new baseline level.
This topic was automatically closed 14 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
